comments.text: i spent a few years in the mid90 s working on the design of  fault tolerant  organizations hoping to create information exchange pathways inside organizations that limited the harm that could be done through the loss or failure of any individual the large scale experiment  the scaleable company that we were building  pretty much failed ended up being rebuilt form the ground up on a different basis using contractor labor in part because i had neither identified nor solved these problems and in part because we were working inside an existing organizational structure and not all the systems for necessary a0decentralization and elimination of single points of failure could be implemented  a0as much as the article s text the image you chose to illustrate it speaks to the most interesting approach to this problem i have seen anyone take to dateabout 20 years ago a good friend was running a nonprofit with a chronically dysfunctional board of directors he gained access to a big pulling boat  8 or 10 big oars on a lifeboat sized wooden hull  i think it was a replica of one of the launches on capt vancouver s ship  and he took the board out for a spin and steered them into serious currents way out in the bay and then disabled the rudder  a0at which point they really had no choice other than a tow from the coast guard but to cooperate  at a truly physical level  to  listen  with their arms and backs and legs to one another s muscles on the other oars and coordinate their efforts if they were to get back to the harbor but whether or not a single experience like that can really change the way people deal with one another is another matter entirely
